title: Three Shires Head Walk Route

nearby.description: Poole's Cavern and Buxton Country Park

images.title: Deego / Three Shires Head
images.caption: The River Dane at Three Shire Heads, where the Derbyshire, Cheshire and Staffordshire boundaries meet. This is a frequently photographed scene and often appears on calendars and postcards.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Three Shires Head Bridge
images.caption: Three Shires Head Bridge. View North up the Valley. Taken in the spring of 2008. The surrounding moorland is a great place for spotting moths and butterflies in the warmer months. The bridge is evidence that this was a historic route used by silk traders from nearby Flash and Hollinsclough to the mills at Macclesfield.

images.title: Joan Priestley / Small cascade at Three Shires Head
images.caption: Small cascade at the site

images.title: Mark Derbyshire / Three Shires Head
images.caption: Beautiful shot of the waterfalls on Christmas day 2008. Swimmers often enjoy the main pool though the water is nearly always cold.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Lovelane Bridge, Peak District National Park
images.caption: Lovelane Bridge, near the car park at the start of the walk. Cows in the pasture half way between Flash and Allgreave. The River Dane is at the bottom of the hill and there is a Scouting camp site at Manor Farm, just through the trees in the centre of the picture. There is a small chapel and a larger cottage at the bridge just out of shot to the left.

images.title: Open gateway above the Dane Valley by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Open gateway above the Dane Valley. View as you head north from the car park.

images.title: The Dane Valley near Knar by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Dane Valley near Knar as you approach Three Shires Head.

images.title: View north from the Packhorse Bridge by John Topping, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View north from the Packhorse Bridge

description: Explore this beautiful section of the Dane Valley and enjoy rivers, old stone bridges and waterfalls on this lovely walk in the Peak District. Three Shires Head is a point on Axe Edge Moor where the counties of Cheshire, Derbyshire and Staffordshire meet. Here you will find a Grade II-listed packhorse bridge over the River Dane. The bridge is thought to have been constructed in the 18th century. It's a delightful area with a number of small waterfalls and the surrounding Peak District scenery to enjoy. The walk begins from a parking area in Gradbach a couple of miles south of Three Shires Head. You then follow the Dane Valley Way and other footpaths to the bridge and the river. Here you will also find Panniers Pool, a popular place for a paddle or swim in the summer months. An alternative route would be to come from Buxton and follow the Dane Valley Way across Axe Edge Moor to the bridge. This is a much longer walk but does pass through the pretty Buxton Country Park on the way. To extend your walking in the area you could visit the fascinating Lud's Church . The deep chasm is located just to the west of the start point of this walk. Just to the south you can climb to The Roaches . This elevated rocky ridge, includes fascinating rock formations and wonderful views of the surrounding countrsyide. It is one of the most popular walks in the Peak District.
